bill_title: require timely honoring of rebates and to provide a private cause of action.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to require timely honoring of rebates and to provide a private cause of action. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Provider," any cellular phone sales or service provider; (2) "Rebate fulfillment company," any third party handling rebate claims on behalf of a cell phone service provider; (3) "Date of issuance," the date on which the customer purchased a good or service for which a rebate was offered. Section 2. Any provider offering a rebate shall pay, or ensure payment, of a valid rebate claim within sixty days of the date of issuance or, in cases where a rebate claim must be mailed in by a customer, within sixty days of the date on which valid rebate claim was mailed. In no instance may a provider or rebate fulfillment company require a customer to mail in a rebate claim later than the date of the next regular billing following the date of issuance. If a provider or rebate fulfillment company dishonors a rebate claim, the reasons for such dishonor shall be provided to the customer, in writing, along with the original rebate claim and attached documentation no later than thirty days from the date on which the rebate claim was mailed. Rebate offers must remain valid for at least nine months from the date of issuance. Any violation of this section is a Class 2 misdemeanor. Section 3. A state's attorney or the attorney general may bring an action for civil damages against any provider or rebate fulfillment company who violates section 2 of this Act, in addition to any other penalties provided by law. The civil damages are limited to: (1) Payment of up to three times the amount of any wrongfully dishonored rebate claim or rebate claim not honored within the time periods specified in this Act, including the cost of investigation and litigation; and (2) Payment in the sum of two thousand dollars for each wrongfully dishonored rebate claim or rebate claim not honored within the time periods specified in this Act. Section 4. Any customer suffering a loss because of a method, act, or practice declared unlawful by section 2 of this Act, may bring a private action to recover actual damages, including amount of the rebate offered, or five hundred dollars, whichever is greater. The court may, in its discretion, award up to three times the actual damages sustained, but not less than five hundred dollars, and may provide such additional relief as it deems necessary or proper. In the event the customer substantially prevails, the court shall award to the plaintiff, in addition to other relief provided in this section, costs and reasonable attorney fees.
